title: How to Delete Cookies on a Mac Desktop & MacBook

steps.title: Open the Safari menu.
steps.content: Open the Safari menu. This menu item is on the top-left side of your Mac's screen when the Safari browser is open. A drop-down menu will appear. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Click Settings….
steps.content: Click Settings… . It's near the top of the Safari drop-down menu.

steps.title: Select the Privacy tab.
steps.content: Select the Privacy tab. You’ll find it at the top center of the Settings window.

steps.title: Click Manage Website Data….
steps.content: Click Manage Website Data… . It's in the middle of the page. On older versions of Mac OS X, this will say Remove All Website Data... instead.

steps.title: Click Remove All.
steps.content: Click Remove All . This button is on the lower left side of the window. If you’d rather delete cookies for individual websites, you can look for them in the list of websites in this window or search for them with the search bar at the top. Click an option in the list and then select Remove .

steps.title: Click Remove Now when prompted.
steps.content: Click Remove Now when prompted. Doing so will clear your Safari browser's cookies. When you’re finished, click Done in the bottom right corner of the window.

steps.title: Clear Safari's cache to get rid of persistent cookies.
steps.content: Clear Safari's cache to get rid of persistent cookies. If you still see cookies popping up after deleting your Mac's stored cookies, you can clear Safari's cache, which will remove all of Safari's input information except for settings and bookmarks. To do so: Click the Safari menu item. Click Settings... Click the Advanced tab. Check the Show features for web developers box at the bottom of the window. Click the Develop menu item. Click Empty Caches . If you want to stop new cookies from showing up, you can also check the Block all cookies box in the Advanced tab of the Settings window.

steps.title: Click the Chrome menu.
steps.content: Click the Chrome menu. This menu item is in the top-left corner of your Mac's screen when the Chrome browser is open. A drop-down menu will appear.

steps.title: Click Clear Browsing Data….
steps.content: Click Clear Browsing Data… . It's near the top of the Chrome drop-down menu. Doing so will open the Browsing Data window.

steps.title: Select a time frame.
steps.content: Select a time frame. Click the drop-down box to the right of the "Time range" heading near the top of the window, then click one of the following options: Last hour Last 24 hours Last 7 days Last 4 weeks All time

steps.title: Check the "Cookies and other site data" box.
steps.content: Check the "Cookies and other site data" box. You can check other boxes in this window as well if you want to remove other types of web data, but you must check the "Cookies and other site data" box to remove Chrome cookies from your Mac.

steps.title: Click Clear data.
steps.content: Click Clear data . It's a blue button in the bottom-right corner of the Browsing Data window. Clicking this will completely clear your Mac's Chrome cookies.

steps.title: Click the History menu.
steps.content: Click the History menu. It's a menu item in the upper-left side of your Mac's screen when Firefox is open. A drop-down menu will appear.

steps.title: Click Clear Recent History….
steps.content: Click Clear Recent History… . This option is in the History drop-down menu. A window will open.

steps.title: Select a time frame.
steps.content: Select a time frame. Click the "Time range to clear:" drop-down box, then click one of the following options: Last Hour Last Two Hours Last Four Hours Today Everything

steps.title: Check the "Cookies" box.
steps.content: Check the "Cookies" box. You can check other boxes on this menu as well, but the "Cookies" box has to be checked in order for Firefox's cookies to be cleared.

steps.title: Click Clear Now.
steps.content: Click Clear Now . It's at the bottom of the window.
